Award.AwardTitle: SI2-SSE: Collaborative Research: A Sustainable Future for the Glue Multi-Dimensional Linked Data Visualization Package

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Glue is a free and open-source application that allows scientists and data scientists to explore relationships within and across related datasets. Glue makes it easy create a wide variety of visualizations (such as scatter plots, bar charts, images) of data, including three dimensional views. What makes Glue unique is its ability to connect datasets together, without merging them into one. Thus, for example, two Earth-based mapping data sets may be connected and jointly visualized by using the coordinates (e.g. latitude and longitude) to glue the maps together, so that when a user selects (e.g. with a lasso tool) regions in one data set, the corresponding selected subset of data will highlight in all related visualizations simultaneously. These ?linked views" are especially powerful across wide varieties of plot types. For example, if a user interested in air traffic control glues a data set with information about the 3D locations of all airplanes to a second data set giving weather information, that user could make a combination of selections that would highlight (on maps, in 3D views, or any other display) planes at particular altitudes where thunderstorms might be likely to occur within a specific period of time. In particular, Glue makes it easy for users to create their own kinds of visualizations, which is important because different disciplines often need very specialized ways of looking at data. The software is already being used widely across several disciplines, in particular, astronomy and medicine, for which has been specially optimized. This project will add new features to make Glue more useful in more fields of science (e.g. bioinformatics, epidemiology) where there is demand for linked-view visualization, as well as making it more accessible as an educational tool. In addition, this project will train new users and developers, who will expand Glue into a much more sustainable community effort.

Glue is an open-source package that allows scientists to explore relationships within and across related datasets, by making it easy for them to make multi-dimensional linked visualizations of datasets, select subsets of data interactively or programmatically in 1, 2, or 3 dimensions, and see those selections propagate live across all open visualizations of the data (e.g. graphs, maps, diagnostics charts). A unique feature of glue is that datasets from different sources can be linked to each other, using user-defined mathematical relationships between sets of data components, which makes it possible to carry out selections across datasets. Glue, written in Python, is designed from the ground-up for multidisciplinary work, and it is currently helping researchers make discoveries in geoscience, genomics, astronomy, and medicine. It is also giving insights into data from outside academia, including open data provided by governments and cities. To become sustainable in the long term, glue development needs to become a community-driven effort. Through tutorial and developer workshops, coding sprints, and strategic collaborations with researchers in several disciplines and experienced open source developers, the glue team will help user communities extend glue by developing new functionality useful within particular fields of research. The team will help users contribute the most widely-needed functionality back to glue, and will recruit active contributors to participate in core glue development. As the community grows, glue development will be guided to focus on several major features useful to the broad research community, including: support for very large datasets, support for running glue fully in the browser (inside Jupyter notebooks and Jupyter Lab), and improved interoperability with third-party tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria

Institution.Name: Harvard University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: PRESIDENT AND FELLOWS OF HARVARD COLLEGE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of the glue software project is to promote and enhance the use of "linked view" data exploration and visualization, across all fields of quantitative research.  In linked view visualization, salient subsets of data displayed across a variety of chart types can be "selected," and selections propagate live across all open views (see the "Principle of Linked Views" figure).  The name "glue" has three meanings, as shown in the provided overview of glue's architecture. 1.) Data sets can be "glued" together, by linking shared attributes, without merging files. 2.) Data displays are "glued" (linked), so that user-defined selections propagate live across all open views. And, 3.) open-source software tools developed independently from the glue project can be "glued" into glue's interface to create new viewers and functionality.

The goal of this NSF SI2-SSE project was to help the glue ecosystem become sustainable  by growing the community of developers through collaborations with researchers in a range of disciplines, as well as by developing critical features for the broad user community, including running glue in the browser, supporting access to large remote datasets, and developing new links to third party software.

Key outcomes include:

  • A series of "glue-con" workshop/hackathons successfully fostered an expanding and active user and developer community around glue. Each glue-con was attended by 20-30 software developers and key glue users from around the world. The workshops were held annually, two at Harvard (Cambridge, MA, 2018 and 2019)  and one at the Flatiron Institute/Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History (New York, NY) in 2020. The glue-con format includes discussion sessions as well as hands-on sprinting, and has consistently yielded prototypes of major new functionality, across several domains of inquiry.  The glue-con series will continue for the foreseeable future.
  • glue was re-engineered to facilitate access to very large and/or remote datasets. Using the new infrastructure, the glue community developed several prototypes for accessing data, including a plugin making it possible to access data from the Gaia satellite, which includes over a billion records, and a plugin for accessing large simulation datasets via an interface to the yt package.  glue was also modified to offer density maps of points, a critical feature when visualizing millions or more points.
  • Our core team, in collaboration with partners at NASA, developed early versions of  "glupyter" which makes it possible to use glue in the browser (see figure) in Jupyter notebooks and JupyterLab. Browser functionality is highly desirable-across all fields of inquiry--as it obviates the need to install any software locally, and can offer access to powerful remote data handling.  So far, glupyter in Jupyter notebooks offers tools to show data in 2-D and 3-D plots, images, histograms, and volume renderings, and glupyter users can make multiple selections that propagate live to all open plots. Under the SI2-SSE award, our team created several Jupyter-based tutorials for glue to demonstrate glupyter in Jupyter notebooks. glupyter has been adopted as a framework on which the Space Telescope Science Institute is building analysis tools for NASA's James Webb Space Telescope.
  • Work on the glue-plot.ly plugin has facilitated 1-click export of glue visualizations to web pages.  A sample of a Figure published in Nature using this system is shown in the Radcliffe Wave figure here, and is live at http://tinyurl.com/RadWave/visuals. 
  • To allow "glue-ing" together of tools, several new plugins were developed.  One of the most versatile plugins allows WorldWide Telescope (an application for advanced visualization of astronomical datasets on the celestial sphere and GIS-style data on the Earth) to be used inside of glue and glupyter, as showin in the "Airplanes over Boston" figure included here. In collaboration with experts at the American Museum of Natural History (AMNH), an OpenSpace plugin has been created, allowing for use of glue as a live data exploration environment on planetarium domes. At glue-con 2020, this functionality was piloted live on the dome of the AMNH Hayden Planetarium.
  • A particularly significant scientific outcome of expert use of glue was the discovery (see the figure and http://tinyurl.com/RadWave) of the "Radcliffe Wave," a fully unexpected gigantic undulating wave of star-forming gas in the Milky Way. Integration of WorldWide Telescope with glue made it possible to contextualize  wave's location and import in the Milky Way--and also made for spectacular images that appeared on many newspaper's and website's front pages in January 2020.
  • Two additional NSF proposals were inspired by this work.  First, a now-funded effort to enhance  glupyter, and a pending proposal to include Augmented Reality output from glue in scholarly publications (see "Next for glue: Augmented Reality" figure).
  • A new series of educational videos, at http://tinyurl.com/10QVizVideos highlights how glue fits into the ecosystem of modern visualization techniques available to scientists.
  • A proposal to use glue to teach Data Science concepts was funded by NASA for $3.2M in Fall 2020.

Last Modified: 02/14/2021
Modified by: Alyssa A Goodman

Images (1 of )
  • This schematic illustrates the three meanings of the glue software's name: 1) glue-ing data sets; 2) glue-ing displays of the data; and 3) glue-ing software tools.
    Alyssa Goodman
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Alyssa A Goodman
    The Overall Architecture of glue
  • This cartoon shows one of the central principles of glue: the abilit to highlight salient features in one display and have the corresponding data highlight automatically in all open displays.
    Michelle Borkin
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Alyssa A Goodman
    The Principle of Linked Views
  • This screenshot shows a user visualizing and exploring data capturing the 3D positions, over time, of airplanes near Boston, MA. The panel at lower left shows the "Earth/Sky Viewer" (WorldWide Telescope) plug-in to glue. Ascending planes are shown in blue, descending in red.
    Alyssa Goodman
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Alyssa A Goodman
    Airplanes over Boston, as seen in glue
  • Looking at airplane flight data in a linked view. Note that descending planes are in red (with straight flight paths) and ascending flights are in blue. This figure is a demonstration of glue running in a "Jupyter" online environment.
    Tom Robitaille
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Alyssa A Goodman
    "glupyter" glue in the browser
  • The "Visuals" page of the Radcliffe Wave's website. The colorful image of the top of the page, generated in glue, shows the wave in the context of the Milky Way, using the WorldWide Telescope plugin. The lower (interactive) image shows output to plot.ly from glue. The "wave" is shown in red.
    A. Goodman & C. Zucker
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Alyssa A Goodman
    The Radcliffe Wave
  • A demonstration figure, showing QR codes that a user can scan with a smartphone to see glue's output in augmented reality, floating over a flat surface (left code) or on a "Merge cube" (right code). Figures are from a pending NSF proposal.
    Alyssa Goodman
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Alyssa A Goodman
    Next for glue: Augmented Reality
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The overarching goal of the glue software project is to promote and enhance the use of "linked view" data exploration and visualization, across all fields of quantitative research. In linked view visualization, salient subsets of data displayed across a variety of chart types can be "selected," and selections propagate live across all open views (see the "Principle of Linked Views" figure). The name "glue" has three meanings, as shown in the provided overview of glue's architecture. 1.) Data sets can be "glued" together, by linking shared attributes, without merging files. 2.) Data displays are "glued" (linked), so that user-defined selections propagate live across all open views. And, 3.) open-source software tools developed independently from the glue project can be "glued" into glue's interface to create new viewers and functionality. The goal of this NSF SI2-SSE project was to help the glue ecosystem become sustainable by growing the community of developers through collaborations with researchers in a range of disciplines, as well as by developing critical features for the broad user community, including running glue in the browser, supporting access to large remote datasets, and developing new links to third party software. Key outcomes include: A series of "glue-con" workshop/hackathons successfully fostered an expanding and active user and developer community around glue. Each glue-con was attended by 20-30 software developers and key glue users from around the world. The workshops were held annually, two at Harvard (Cambridge, MA, 2018 and 2019) and one at the Flatiron Institute/Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History (New York, NY) in 2020. The glue-con format includes discussion sessions as well as hands-on sprinting, and has consistently yielded prototypes of major new functionality, across several domains of inquiry. The glue-con series will continue for the foreseeable future. glue was re-engineered to facilitate access to very large and/or remote datasets. Using the new infrastructure, the glue community developed several prototypes for accessing data, including a plugin making it possible to access data from the Gaia satellite, which includes over a billion records, and a plugin for accessing large simulation datasets via an interface to the yt package. glue was also modified to offer density maps of points, a critical feature when visualizing millions or more points. Our core team, in collaboration with partners at NASA, developed early versions of "glupyter" which makes it possible to use glue in the browser (see figure) in Jupyter notebooks and JupyterLab. Browser functionality is highly desirable-across all fields of inquiry--as it obviates the need to install any software locally, and can offer access to powerful remote data handling. So far, glupyter in Jupyter notebooks offers tools to show data in 2-D and 3-D plots, images, histograms, and volume renderings, and glupyter users can make multiple selections that propagate live to all open plots. Under the SI2-SSE award, our team created several Jupyter-based tutorials for glue to demonstrate glupyter in Jupyter notebooks. glupyter has been adopted as a framework on which the Space Telescope Science Institute is building analysis tools for NASA's James Webb Space Telescope. Work on the glue-plot.ly plugin has facilitated 1-click export of glue visualizations to web pages. A sample of a Figure published in Nature using this system is shown in the Radcliffe Wave figure here, and is live at http://tinyurl.com/RadWave/visuals. To allow "glue-ing" together of tools, several new plugins were developed. One of the most versatile plugins allows WorldWide Telescope (an application for advanced visualization of astronomical datasets on the celestial sphere and GIS-style data on the Earth) to be used inside of glue and glupyter, as showin in the "Airplanes over Boston" figure included here. In collaboration with experts at the American Museum of Natural History (AMNH), an OpenSpace plugin has been created, allowing for use of glue as a live data exploration environment on planetarium domes. At glue-con 2020, this functionality was piloted live on the dome of the AMNH Hayden Planetarium. A particularly significant scientific outcome of expert use of glue was the discovery (see the figure and http://tinyurl.com/RadWave) of the "Radcliffe Wave," a fully unexpected gigantic undulating wave of star-forming gas in the Milky Way. Integration of WorldWide Telescope with glue made it possible to contextualize wave's location and import in the Milky Way--and also made for spectacular images that appeared on many newspaper's and website's front pages in January 2020. Two additional NSF proposals were inspired by this work. First, a now-funded effort to enhance glupyter, and a pending proposal to include Augmented Reality output from glue in scholarly publications (see "Next for glue: Augmented Reality" figure). A new series of educational videos, at http://tinyurl.com/10QVizVideos highlights how glue fits into the ecosystem of modern visualization techniques available to scientists. A proposal to use glue to teach Data Science concepts was funded by NASA for $3.2M in Fall 2020. Last Modified: 02/14/2021 Submitted by: Alyssa A Goodman
